Russia cuts the shipment of natural gas to Ukraine over a price dispute.
Ariel Sharon, Prime Minister of Israel, suffers a severe stroke and cerebral hemorrhage.
A hotel in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, collapses, killing 76 pilgrims visiting to perform Hajj.
A stampede during the Stoning of the Devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills 362 pilgrims.
NASA's Stardust mission successfully ends, the first to return dust from a comet.
Ellen Johnson Sirleaf assumes office as President of Liberia, the first female elected head of state in Africa.
NASA launches the first space mission to Pluto as a rocket hurls the New Horizons spacecraft on a 9-year journey.
Pope Benedict XVI issues his first encycylical, Deus caritas est.
Celebrations are held in Salzburg and around the world, for the 250th anniversary of the birth of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.
Egyptian passenger ferry, MS al-Salam Boccaccio 98 carrying more than 1,400 people, sinks in the Red Sea off the Saudi coast, with only 388 rescued.
The Wowowee stampede at the PhilSports Arena in Pasig City, Philippines, kills 74 people and leaves 600 injured.
February 26 - The 2006 Winter Olympics are held in Turin, Italy.
A massive mudslide occurs in Southern Leyte, Philippines; the official death toll is set at 1,126.
Pasta de Conchos mine disaster: Sixty-five miners die after becoming trapped underground, following an explosion in Nueva Rosita, Mexico.
The final contact attempt with Pioneer 10 receives no response.
NASA's Cassini-Huygens spacecraft discovers geysers of a liquid substance shooting from Saturn's moon Enceladus, signaling a possible presence of water.
NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter enters orbit around Mars.
The United Nations General Assembly votes overwhelmingly to establish the United Nations Human Rights Council.
Jack Dorsey, Noah Glass, Biz Stone, and Evan Williams found the popular social-networking service Twitter. They officially launch the site later in the year.
A scramjet jet engine, HyShot III, designed to fly at 7 times the speed of sound, is successfully tested at Woomera, South Australia.
A swan with Avian Flu is discovered in Cellardyke in Fife, Scotland (the first case in the United Kingdom).
A fire at the Brand India Fair, Victoria Park, Meerut, Uttar Pradesh, India, kills at least 100.
The European Space Agency's Venus Express spaceprobe enters Venus' orbit.
Nuclear program of Iran: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad confirms that Iran has successfully produced a few grams of low-grade enriched uranium.

Iran announces a deal with Russia, involving a joint uranium enrichment firm on Russian soil; 9 days later Iran announces that it will not move all activity to Russia, thus leading to a de facto termination of the deal.
Over The Hedge, the first DreamWorks Animation film to be by Paramount Pictures premieres in theatres.
East Timor's Foreign Minister José Ramos-Horta officially requests military assistance from the governments of Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia, and Portugal.
A 6.3 magnitude earthquake strikes central Java in Indonesia, killing more than 6,000, injuring at least 36,000 and leaving some 1.5 million people homeless.

Sidoarjo mud flow: The world's biggest mud volcano is created by the blowout of a natural gas well being drilled in the subdistrict of Porong, Sidoarjo in East Java, Indonesia. This results in displacement of more than 11,000 persons from 8 villages, as well as damage to road and power infrastructures. Several (Twenty-five) factories are also abandoned.
Montenegro declares independence after a May 21 referendum. The state union of Serbia and Montenegro is dissolved on June 5, leaving Serbia as the successor state.
July 9 - The 2006 FIFA World Cup begins in Germany.
The first Kazakh space satellite KazSat-1 is launched.
Former Beatle Paul McCartney turns 64 after writing "When I'm Sixty-Four" at age 16.
Operation Summer Rains: Israel launches an offensive against militants in Gaza.
The United States Armed Forces withdraws its forces in Iceland, thereby disbanding the Iceland Defense Force.
The Qinghai-Tibet Railway launches a trial operation, making Tibet the last province-level entity of China to have a conventional railway.
The Nathu La pass between India and China, sealed during the Sino-Indian War, re-opens for trade after 44 years.
Italy wins its fourth FIFA World Cup title.
S7 Airlines Flight 778 crashes into a concrete barrier shortly after landing, killing at least 122 people and leaving many injured.
Pakistan International Airlines Flight 688 crashes in Multan, Pakistan, shortly after takeoff.
A series of coordinated bomb attacks strikes several commuter trains in Mumbai, India, during the evening rush hour.
2006 Lebanon War: Israeli troops invade Lebanon in response to Hezbollah kidnapping 2 Israeli soldiers and killing 3. Hezbollah declares open war against Israel 2 days later.
The SS Nomadic, the last floating link to Titanic, returns home to a large reception in Belfast, Northern Ireland.
A resolution to end the 2006 Lebanon War is unanimously accepted by the United Nations Security Council.
Pulkovo Aviation Enterprise Flight 612 crashes near the Russian border in Ukraine, killing 171 people, including 45 children.
The ICM awards Grigori Perelman the Fields Medal for proving the Poincaré conjecture, one of 7 Millennium Prize Problems; Perelman refuses the medal.
The International Astronomical Union defines 'planet' at its 26th General Assembly, demoting Pluto to the status of 'dwarf planet' more than 70 years after its discovery.
Dawson College shooting in Montreal: One killed, nineteen injured.

Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra of Thailand declares a state of emergency in Bangkok as members of the Royal Thai Army stage a coup d'état. The army announces the removal of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra from power.
Gol Transportes Aéreos Flight 1907 (Boeing 737-800) collides with a business jet over the Amazon rainforest, killing all 155 on board.
Aleksandër Moisiu University opens in Durrës, Albania.
North Korea claims to have conducted its first-ever nuclear test.
South Korean Ban Ki-moon is elected as the new Secretary-General of the United Nations.
The population of the United States exceeds 300 million.
ADC Airlines Flight 53 crashes shortly after takeoff in Nigeria, killing 96 people.
No. 5, 1948 by Jackson Pollock becomes the most expensive painting after it is sold privately for $140 million.
Former President of Iraq Saddam Hussein is sentenced to death by hanging by the Iraqi Special Tribunal.
Mercury transits the sun. It is visible from the Americas, Eastern China, Japan, Australia, and Polynesia.
The former Soviet republic of South Ossetia holds a referendum on independence from Georgia.
Al Jazeera launches its English-language news channel, Al Jazeera English.
A series of car bombs and mortar attacks in Sadr City, Baghdad, kill at least 215 people and injure 257 other people.
Typhoon Durian triggers a massive mudslide and kills at least 720 people in Albay province on the island of Luzon in the Philippines.
The military seizes power in Fiji, in a coup d'état led by Commodore Josaia Vorenathalie qe "Frank" Bainimarama.
Felipe Calderón sends the Mexican military to combat the drug cartels and put down the violence in the state of Michoacán, initiating the Mexican Drug War.
Swift raids: Homeland Security police detain workers at 6 meatpacking plants in the midwestern U.S.
The Chinese River Dolphin or Baiji becomes extinct.
Ethiopia admits its troops have intervened in Somalia.
An oil pipeline explodes in Nigeria's commercial capital, Lagos, killing at least 200 people.
Basque nationalist group ETA detonates a van bomb at Madrid-Barajas Airport in Madrid, Spain, ending a nine-month ceasefire.
